_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Due to stringent release prevention equipment and policies, there has been no accidental release during this period that caused any onsite death, injury or significant property damage, or known offsite death, injury, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.

i-8  Emergency Response Plan
The WTP maintains a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials. The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas. More on the emergency response information is provided in Section 7 of the Plan.

To ensure proper functioning, the facility's emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced. In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within the covered processes that would require a modified emergency response.

The City participates in the Contra Costa County Community Warning System.  This emergency warning system provides for the alert and notification of the community in the case of potentially harmful releases.  This Community Warning System includes sirens and emergency alert receivers for schools, daycare, senior centers, and hospitals throughout the industrial corridor. Also included is the most advanced technology for emergency notification, such as automated radio, TV, and cable broadcasts for use throughout the County. The Community Warning System provides for on-going community outreach to educate the public about the most effective response (usually shelter-in-place) when the sirens sound.

i-9  Continuous Efforts to Improve Safety
Several developments and findings have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of our accidental release prevention program. There is a commitment to continue to improve safety by reviewing, revising

, and enhancing written procedures as well as implementing other action items.  These include evaluation of integral yoke assemblies for the chlorinators, improvements to the chlorine scrubber operational procedures, and improvements to the response time for placing a water deluge on an ammonia leak.  All are expected to be resolved by November 2002. None of the action items resulting from the PHA are critical or essential; rather they represent enhancements or continuous improvement.  

i-10  External Events Analysis (Cal-ARP Only) DELETED 6-1-04

dent that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring. All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years. These are described in more detail in Section 6.9.

Employee Participation. The WTP believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the Process Safety regulations, including information resulting from process hazard analyses. This participation is described in more detail in Section 6.10.

Hot Work Permit Program.  Pertinent personnel are notified when hot work (i.e., any spark-producing operation including grinding, burning, welding, brazing) is to be performed in a unit and they assure that appropriate safety precautions are taken prior to initiation of the work.  The hot work permit satisfies all of the requirements of Cal-OSHA Regulations. Hot Work permits and procedures are described in more detail in Section 6.11.

Contractors. On occasion, the WTP hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, an evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out. The WTP has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the covered processes. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur. This practice is described in more detail in Section 6.12.

i-7   Five-Year Accident History
The WTP has had an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last 5 years.

ailable to all employees.

The plant also trains and requires all employees to be familiar with the Operations Plan and Plant Operations Manual kept on site.  Stationary source safety and environmental programs include the following: regular tailgate talks with all plant staff present; semi-annual Safety Meetings, periodic Self-Contained Breathing Apparatus (SCBA) training, including refresher courses for all staff at the point a new employee is hired; instruction on handling of chemicals and the use or Personal Protective Equipment (PPE).

In addition to the above, all employees receive periodic training in the City's Hazard Communications Policy, including instruction on how to read and understand Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) posted at the WTP, and the City's Injury & Illness Prevention Plan (IIPP).

In addition, there are regularly scheduled, and unscheduled, safety inspections of all city facilities by the Public Services Department Safety Committee, which operates in conjunction with the City of Pittsburg Safety Committee. The latter group involves itself in generalized safety concerns across all city departments, while the Public Services committee specializes in maintenance and operations functions of the department.

The WTP has also conducted studies and implemented safety programs, which are included as a part of its Process Safety Management program.  These include periodic Process Hazard Analysis Studies, seismic analyses and prevention program basics such as Management of Change and Incident Investigation.  The plant has elected to include both chemical processes into it's Process Safety Management Program even though ammonia is not covered under the OSHA regulation and is eligible for a Program Level 2 prevention program under EPA and State regulations.

i-3  Description Of The Plant And The Regulated Substances Handled
The Pittsburg WTP began operation in 1953, with a rated capacity of 8 million gallons per day, for the treatment and disinfectio

n of raw water. The plant operates as a division of the Public Services Department of the City of Pittsburg.  The facility underwent modernization and upgrades in 1976-1977, which increased the rated capacity to 16 million gallons per day (mgd). In 1988-1990, the facility was modernized and upgraded once more, and while designed for production of up to 32 mgd it currently operates at a maximum of 24 mgd by a permit granted by the California Department of Health Services. In 1998 the plant replaced its on-site 6 million gallon reservoir. The systems for handling chlorine and ammonia were installed during the 1988-1990 modernization. 

Chlorine is used at the WTP to disinfect raw water drawn from the Contra Costa Canal or from wells operated by the City.  Chlorine is typically packaged as a liquefied gas under pressure in steel containers. One ton cylinders of Chlorine are used at the plant, thus exceeding the 2000-pound threshold amount set by the EPA, 1500 pounds set by OSHA and the 100-pound limit set by the State of California.

Anhydrous Ammonia is used at the Plant in combination with chlorine, to control the amount of trihalomethanes (THMs) in potable water. The ammonia system is made up of the ammonia supply vessel, piping and valves. The storage vessel capacity does not exceed the minimum EPA or OSHA threshold of 10,000 pounds, but does exceed the California Cal-ARP threshold quantity of 500 pounds.

The limits of the processes include all the equipment, facilities and procedures to handle both ammonia and chlorine while it is under pressure.  Once these chemicals reach the mixing equipment, they are no longer in concentrations that would make them hazardous and pose little risk to workers and no risk to the public.

Specific quantities handled and details of the systems are included in the details of the applicable compliance submittals to both EPA and Contra Costa County.

ve and engineering controls). Those recommendations that are planned for implementation are discussed in Planned Changes to Improve Safety. Those applicable safeguards that have already been implemented or that were part of the original design are summarized below and described in more detail in section 6.2.5. These safeguards prevent, detect, or mitigate accidental releases of regulated substances.

All covered processes have control systems designed to maintain operating parameters (temperature. pressures, flow, level, etc.) within allowable limits. The covered processes are also equipped with alarms to alert personnel when the operating parameters exceed the allowable limits. The stationary source developed procedures and conducts training of personnel to familiarize them with the consequences of exceeding~ allowable limits (safety and operability) to ensure the correct response to the alarms. The following summarizes chemical-specific safeguards also exist at the stationary source and are presented in more detail in the Process Hazard Analysis section of the Plan

	Release Detection
1.	Chlorine monitor / detector
2.	Pressure monitors in Control House
3.	Plant staffing and surveillance 24 hours per day
4.	Additional staffing for material handling operations during daylight hours

	Release Containment/Control 
1.	Automatic activation of scrubber to prevent Chlorine release outside a containment building
2.	Process relief valves to prevent catastrophic release from inadvertent overpressure
3.	Valves to permit isolation of the materials form potential leaks
4.	Curbing to contain liquid releases and reduce vaporization
5.	Redundant equipment and instrumentation 

	Release Mitigation
1.	Fire suppression and extinguishing systems for Chlorine building
2.	Water deluge system for Ammonia 
3.	Trained emergency response personnel
4.	Personal protective equipment including self-contained breathing apparatus
5.	Tight building enclosure for Chlorine
6.	Backup generators for

power interruption

i-6.3  Prevention Program Summary
The WTP has taken the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention program requirements set forth under OSHA, EPA and State process safety regulations.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that are in place.

Process Safety Information. The WTP maintains a record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes.  This information is important for conducting hazard studies, ensuring adequate facility modification and providing effective training for plant personnel.  These are described in more detail in Section 6.1.

Process Hazard Analysis. The WTP conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with the covered processes are identified and controlled efficiently. The methodology used to carry out these analyses is a HAZOP study. Findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner. The most recent PHA/update was performed on October 18, 2001. There was also a detailed seismic assessment conducted in 1995.  The PHA and its results are described in more detail in Section 6.2.

Operating Procedures. For the purposes of safely conducting activities within the covered processes, the WTP maintains written operating procedures. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes. These are described in more detail in Section 6.3.

Training. The WTP has a training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating and maintaining the processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes. Refresher training is provided at least every year and more frequently

Executive Summary
i-1  Background
In accordance with regulations detailed in Title 40, Chapter 68, as promulgated by the Environmental Protection Agency and Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 of the California Code of Regulations, the City of Pittsburg submits this risk management plan (RMP) for the operations of their Water Treatment Plant (WTP) in Pittsburg California.  The City provides potable water to their service area, which coincides with the city limits.  As a part of this operation, hazardous materials are used to meet the quality demands of our customers and compliance with regulations, which protect the public health.

A copy of the Plant's Accidental Release Prevention Program policy is included as Figure I-1.  This policy addresses the City's commitment to preventing accidental releases and to being prepared to respond in the unlikely event that a release should occur.  This RMP is a summary of the specific programs in place, which are incorporated, and a part of our overall safety efforts.

i-2  Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policy
The WTP is owned by the City of Pittsburg and is located at 300 Olympia Drive.  It operates as a division of its Public Services Department. The City is committed to providing needed services to local residents, businesses and visitors to Pittsburg, and to being a positive influence on the community. This includes respect for the safety of the public and city employees, as well as concern for the environment.

The City values its employees' efforts to find safer, more effective and more efficient ways of providing service to the community.  Regular safety meetings are held, and employees are encouraged to look for ways to reduce the risk to the employees, to the community or to the environment through the implementation of new technology and procedures. This commitment to safe and environmentally sound operations is documented in the policy and compliance manuals, and the facility mission statement, which are av

DELETED 6-1-04

i-6  General Accident Prevention Program and Chemical-specific Prevention Steps
i-6.1  Management System
The Pittsburg WTP has developed a management system to plan, organize, implement and control the risk management program elements. This system satisfies the requirements of the regulations, and ensures that risk management program elements are developed and continually improved. All records associated with the prevention program elements are retained for a minimum of five years, unless otherwise specified in the regulations.

o	Planning - The Plant has an overall risk management policy that clearly identifies the goals and objectives of the risk management program.
o	Organizing - The Plant Supervisor was designated as the person responsible for the risk management program elements. While this authority may be further delegated to subordinate staff, contract workers or consultants, the  of the facility does not permit such assignments at this time.
o	Implementing - The Plant Supervisor is responsible for ensuring all appropriate persons are trained in risk management procedures, implementation of the procedures, and documentation. Refresher training is provided on an as-needed basis, but is conducted at a minimum following any changes to procedures, or following reauthorization.
o	Controlling - The Plant Supervisor and his designees will conduct periodic internal reviews or audits against the goals and objectives of the program element. Annually, these procedures are reviewed and revised as needed to ensure they remain accurate and reflect current practices.

i-6.2  Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
The prevention programs described in the following section represent integrated administrative controls intended to ensure the safety of workers, the public, and the environment. Many of these prevention programs (e.g., PHA's. Compliance audits, incident investigation) result in the development and implementation of additional safeguards (administrati

as needed. The training programs are described in more detail in Section 6.4.

Mechanical Integrity. The WTP carries out maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes: emergency scrubber, one-ton chlorine cylinders, piping systems, relief and vent systems, leak detectors and controls. Qualified personnel, who have received previous training in maintenance practices, carry out maintenance operations. Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training as needed. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner. The mechanical integrity elements are described in more detail in Section 6.5.

Management of Change. Written procedures will be used at the WTP to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification. The elements of Management of Change are described in more detail in Section 6.6.


Pre-startup Reviews. Pre-startup safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted at the WTP.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation. These reviews are described in more detail in Section 6.7.

Compliance Audits. The WTP conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the Process Safety Regulations are being implemented.  These audits are carried out periodically and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner. These audits are described in more detail in Section 6.8.
